name: Coasts
tagline: Audubon's Coasts initiative focuses on the most threatened and iconic bird species that rely on coastal habitats—estuaries, islands, beaches, and the marine environment—throughout the hemisphere.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: Protecting and restoring coastlines will strengthen populations of shorebirds while preserving the places they need to survive throughout their lives. The work needed to accomplish this goal will also protect coastal communities against the threat of sea-level rise due to a changing climate.  By focusing on the biggest threats to 16 flagship bird species and the places they depend on, we will maximize our conservation impact and help build resilient coastlines. Those 16 flagship species represent at least 375 others as well as the ecosystems upon which they depend.

list: Guide populations of 16 flagship species on a path to recovery and stability by reducing threats at 500 of the most important sites throughout the Western Hemisphere.
Protect and/or enhance the resiliency of 300,000 acres of coastal habitats that are essential to flagship species.
Strengthen coastal policies that will promote healthy coastal ecosystems and adaptability to future change for the benefit of birds, other wildlife and people.

Ensure sustainable forage fisheries through the development of management plans for key fish species, following the California model, and reduce threats to coastal birds from oil/gas development and transportation.
Develop am integrated and unified platform to collect data and measure outcomes of conservation actions and evaluate progress towards goals.
Expand the Coastal Stewardship Program to include 10,000 volunteers, 130 chapters, 13 state programs, and new partners to support conservation at 500 priority sites.
Develop a diverse communications strategy to support on-the-ground stewardship and other conservation strategies such that 250,000 people are moved to take action to advance costal bird conservation.
